problems.title: **URL Shortener** (bit.ly/TinyURL)
problems.description: Design a service that generates short URLs and redirects users to the original long URLs.
problems.statement:
Design a URL shortening service like bit.ly or TinyURL.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How users submit long URLs and receive short URLs
- How the system handles redirection from short to long URLs
- Your choice of database(s) and what they store
- Any APIs or services your system exposes

Focus on the core functionality first. We'll explore scalability, performance, and edge cases in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Image Sharing Service** (Instagram/Imgur)
problems.description: Design a platform where users can upload, store, and share images with metadata like captions and tags.
problems.statement:
Design an image sharing service like Instagram or Imgur.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How users upload images to the service
- Where and how images are stored (blob storage)
- How users view and retrieve images
- Your choice of database(s) for metadata (captions, tags, user info)
- Basic API endpoints your service exposes

Focus on core upload/storage/retrieval functionality. We'll explore image processing, CDNs, and scaling in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Notification Service** (Twilio/OneSignal)
problems.description: Design a service that sends notifications to users across multiple channels like email, SMS, and push notifications.
problems.statement:
Design a notification service like Twilio or OneSignal.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How applications request notifications to be sent
- Support for multiple channels (email, SMS, push notifications)
- How you route notifications to the appropriate channel
- Your choice of database(s) and what they store
- How you track delivery status and handle failures

Focus on core notification delivery. We'll explore user preferences, templates, and scaling in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Social Media Feed** (BlueSky/Threads)
problems.description: Design a social media platform that displays personalized feeds of posts from users you follow.
problems.statement:
Design a social media feed system like BlueSky or Threads.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How users create and publish posts
- How users follow other users
- How the system generates a personalized feed for each user
- Your choice of database(s) and what they store
- Any APIs or services your system exposes

Focus on the core feed functionality. We'll explore ranking algorithms, scalability, and real-time updates in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Web Crawler** (Googlebot/Ahrefs)
problems.description: Design a distributed web crawler that discovers, fetches, and indexes web pages across the internet.
problems.statement:
Design a web crawler system like Googlebot or Ahrefs.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How the crawler discovers and queues URLs to visit
- How pages are fetched, parsed, and processed
- Your choice of database(s) and what they store
- How you prevent duplicate crawling of the same URLs
- Any politeness policies (rate limiting, robots.txt)

Focus on the core crawling mechanism. We'll explore distributed crawling, scalability, and content extraction in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Real-Time Analytics System** (Google Analytics/Adobe Analytics)
problems.description: Design a system that collects, processes, and visualizes user behavior analytics from websites and applications in real-time.
problems.statement:
Design a real-time analytics system like Google Analytics or Adobe Analytics.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How events are collected from websites/apps and ingested into the system
- How events are processed and aggregated
- Your choice of database(s) and what they store
- How users query and visualize metrics/reports
- Real-time vs. batch processing components

Focus on core analytics functionality. We'll explore scalability, data accuracy, and advanced features in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Distributed Cache** (Redis/Memcached)
problems.description: Design a high-performance distributed caching system that stores key-value pairs in memory across multiple nodes.
problems.statement:
Design a distributed cache system like Redis or Memcached.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How clients store and retrieve key-value pairs
- Your cache eviction policy (what happens when memory is full)
- How data is distributed across multiple cache nodes
- Data structures you'll support (strings, lists, sets, etc.)
- Whether and how you'll handle persistence

Focus on the core caching functionality. We'll explore replication, consistency, and failure handling in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Workflow Orchestration System** (Airflow/Temporal)
problems.description: Design a system that schedules and executes complex workflows with task dependencies and state management.
problems.statement:
Design a workflow orchestration system like Airflow or Temporal.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How users define workflows and task dependencies (DAGs)
- How tasks are scheduled and executed by workers
- Your choice of database(s) for workflow state and metadata
- How you handle task failures and retries
- How users monitor workflow execution and view logs

Focus on core orchestration functionality. We'll explore distributed execution, backfilling, and advanced scheduling in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Chat Application** (WhatsApp/Slack)
problems.description: Design a real-time chat application supporting one-on-one and group messaging with message history.
problems.statement:
Design a chat application like WhatsApp or Slack.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How users send and receive messages in real-time
- Support for one-on-one and group conversations
- How messages are stored and retrieved (message history)
- Your choice of database(s) and what they store
- How you handle online/offline status

Focus on core messaging functionality. We'll explore scalability, message delivery guarantees, and features like read receipts in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Video Conferencing System** (Zoom/Teams)
problems.description: Design a video conferencing platform that enables real-time audio and video communication between multiple participants.
problems.statement:
Design a video conferencing system like Zoom or Microsoft Teams.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How audio and video streams are transmitted between participants
- Your architecture for handling multi-party calls
- How users join/create meetings
- Your choice of database(s) and what they store
- Whether you'll use peer-to-peer or server-based streaming

Focus on core video/audio functionality. We'll explore scalability, quality optimization, and features like screen sharing in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Pub/Sub Messaging System** (Kafka/RabbitMQ)
problems.description: Design a message broker that enables asynchronous communication between publishers and subscribers using topics or queues.
problems.statement:
Design a pub/sub messaging system like Kafka or RabbitMQ.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How publishers send messages to topics/queues
- How subscribers consume messages from topics/queues
- Your message storage and retention strategy
- Your choice of database(s) or storage layer
- How you handle message ordering and delivery guarantees

Focus on core messaging functionality. We'll explore scalability, fault tolerance, and advanced patterns in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Video Streaming Platform** (Netflix/YouTube)
problems.description: Design a platform that allows users to upload, store, and stream video content with adaptive quality.
problems.statement:
Design a video streaming platform like Netflix or YouTube.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How videos are uploaded and processed (encoding/transcoding)
- Where and how video files are stored
- How users stream videos with adaptive bitrate streaming
- Your choice of database(s) for metadata (titles, descriptions, user data)
- How you use CDNs for content delivery

Focus on core video delivery functionality. We'll explore recommendations, live streaming, and global scale in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Live Streaming Platform** (Twitch/YouTube Live)
problems.description: Design a platform that enables real-time broadcasting of live video content to thousands of concurrent viewers.
problems.statement:
Design a live streaming platform like Twitch or YouTube Live.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How streamers broadcast live video to your platform
- How live streams are ingested, processed, and distributed
- How viewers watch streams with low latency
- Your choice of database(s) for metadata and chat
- How you handle transcoding and CDN distribution

Focus on core live streaming delivery. We'll explore chat systems, DVR/rewind, and scaling to millions of viewers in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Content Delivery Network** (Cloudflare/Akamai)
problems.description: Design a globally distributed network that caches and delivers content from edge servers close to end users.
problems.statement:
Design a content delivery network (CDN) like Cloudflare or Akamai.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How edge servers (POPs) are distributed globally
- How content is cached at edge locations
- How users are routed to the nearest edge server
- Your cache invalidation/purging strategy
- How origin servers interact with edge servers

Focus on core content caching and delivery. We'll explore cache strategies, anycast routing, and advanced features in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Payment Processing System** (Stripe/PayPal)
problems.description: Design a system that processes online payments securely with support for multiple payment methods and currencies.
problems.statement:
Design a payment processing system like Stripe or PayPal.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How payment requests are initiated and processed
- Payment flow stages (authorization, capture, settlement)
- Your choice of database(s) for transaction records
- How you ensure consistency and handle failures/retries
- Integration with external payment gateways (banks, card networks)

Focus on core payment processing. We'll explore fraud detection, reconciliation, and idempotency in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Stock Trading Platform** (Robinhood/E*TRADE)
problems.description: Design a platform that allows users to buy and sell stocks with real-time pricing and order execution.
problems.statement:
Design a stock trading platform like Robinhood or E*TRADE.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How users place buy and sell orders
- How orders are matched and executed
- Your choice of database(s) for portfolios and transaction history
- How you handle real-time stock price updates
- How you ensure consistency and prevent issues like overselling

Focus on core trading functionality. We'll explore order types, settlement, and high-frequency trading in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Seat Booking System** (Ticketmaster/Fandango)
problems.description: Design a system that allows users to search, select, and book seats for events with concurrency control.
problems.statement:
Design a seat booking system like Ticketmaster or Fandango.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How users search for events and view available seats
- How seat selection and reservation works (preventing double-booking)
- Your choice of database(s) for inventory and bookings
- How you handle concurrent booking requests with locking
- The checkout and payment confirmation flow

Focus on core booking functionality. We'll explore scalability, reservation timeouts, and waitlists in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **E-commerce Inventory Management** (Amazon/Shopify)
problems.description: Design a system that tracks product inventory across warehouses and ensures accurate stock levels during orders.
problems.statement:
Design an e-commerce inventory management system like Amazon or Shopify.

**Your task:** Create a high-level system design diagram and describe the key components. Include:

- How inventory levels are tracked across multiple warehouses
- How stock is reserved when orders are placed
- Your choice of database(s) for inventory and orders
- How you handle concurrent orders and prevent overselling
- How inventory updates from restocking and returns are processed

Focus on core inventory management. We'll explore warehouse selection strategies, inventory reconciliation, and reserved stock handling in follow-up questions.

problems.title: **Collaborative Document Editor** (Google Docs/Word Online)
problems.description: Design a real-time collaborative document editing system supporting multiple simultaneous users.
problems.statement:
Design a system that allows multiple users to edit the same document simultaneously with real-time updates.

**Draw and describe** your high-level architecture. Consider:
- How users see each other's changes instantly
- How you'll handle conflicting edits
- What happens when users have poor connectivity
- How documents are stored and retrieved

In follow-up steps, we'll explore conflict resolution strategies, operational transformation, presence awareness, and scaling considerations. Focus on the core data flow for now.

problems.title: **Multiplayer Game Server** (Valorant/WoW)
problems.description: Design a low-latency multiplayer game server supporting thousands of concurrent players.
problems.statement:
Design a system that enables thousands of players to interact in real-time with minimal lag.

**Draw and describe** your high-level architecture. Consider:
- How you'll keep player actions synchronized across clients
- Managing game state updates with low latency
- Handling player disconnections and reconnections
- Supporting matchmaking and player sessions

In follow-up steps, we'll explore client-server authority models, lag compensation techniques, state reconciliation, anti-cheat mechanisms, and horizontal scaling. Start with the core gameplay loop.

problems.title: **Live Collaborative Whiteboard** (Miro/Figma)
problems.description: Design an infinite canvas whiteboard supporting real-time collaboration with rich visual elements.
problems.statement:
Design a system where multiple users can draw, add shapes, and collaborate on an infinite canvas in real-time.

**Draw and describe** your high-level architecture. Consider:
- How changes to objects are broadcast to all participants
- Rendering updates efficiently across large canvases
- Tracking cursor positions and user presence
- Managing permissions and access control
- Handling offline edits and synchronization

In follow-up steps, we'll explore CRDT vs OT approaches, viewport optimization, vector rendering strategies, and conflict-free merging. Focus on the collaborative update flow.

problems.title: **Metrics Monitoring System** (Prometheus/Datadog)
problems.description: Design a time-series metrics system for monitoring application and infrastructure performance at scale.
problems.statement:
Design a system that collects, stores, and visualizes millions of metrics per second from distributed applications.

**Draw and describe** your high-level architecture. Consider:
- How metrics are collected from thousands of hosts/services
- Storing time-series data efficiently for fast queries
- Querying and aggregating metrics across dimensions
- Triggering alerts when thresholds are breached
- Handling high ingestion rates and data retention

In follow-up steps, we'll explore time-series databases, cardinality management, downsampling strategies, pull vs push models, and distributed querying. Focus on the ingestion and query path.

problems.title: **Distributed Logging System** (ELK/Splunk)
problems.description: Design a centralized logging platform for collecting, indexing, and searching logs across distributed systems.
problems.statement:
Design a system that ingests billions of log events daily from distributed services and enables fast searching and analysis.

**Draw and describe** your high-level architecture. Consider:
- How logs flow from applications to central storage
- Indexing structured and unstructured log data
- Supporting fast full-text search across massive datasets
- Managing different retention policies per log type
- Handling burst traffic and backpressure

In follow-up steps, we'll explore log parsing pipelines, inverted indexes, sharding strategies, schema evolution, and cost optimization through tiered storage. Focus on ingestion and query paths.

problems.title: **Distributed Tracing System** (AWS X-Ray/Google Cloud Trace)
problems.description: Design a distributed tracing platform to track requests across microservices and identify performance bottlenecks.
problems.statement:
Design a system that traces requests as they flow through dozens of microservices, capturing latency and dependencies.

**Draw and describe** your high-level architecture. Consider:
- How trace data is collected from instrumented services
- Linking related operations across service boundaries
- Storing and querying trace spans efficiently
- Sampling strategies to manage data volume
- Visualizing request paths and identifying bottlenecks

In follow-up steps, we'll explore context propagation, tail-based sampling, trace aggregation, anomaly detection, and storage optimization. Focus on the trace collection and correlation flow.

problems.title: **Application Performance Monitoring** (AppDynamics/DataTrace)
problems.description: Design an APM system that provides deep visibility into application performance and user experience.
problems.statement:
Design a system that monitors application health, tracks user transactions, and identifies performance issues in production.

**Draw and describe** your high-level architecture. Consider:
- How you'll instrument applications to capture performance data
- Tracking end-to-end transactions across tiers (web, app, database)
- Detecting anomalies and performance degradation automatically
- Correlating application metrics with infrastructure health
- Supporting root cause analysis and code-level diagnostics

In follow-up steps, we'll explore agent instrumentation, baseline detection, dependency mapping, real user monitoring, and metric aggregation strategies. Focus on data collection and analysis paths.
